Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Dysphagia and chest pain for the past 4 months

Present Illness.Onset: Onset 4 months ago, at home, gradual onset, no prodromal symptoms noted. Potential cause suspected to be progressive disease due to advanced age.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Dysphagia, initially with solid food, progressively worsening to include semi-solid and liquid food, and now saliva. Associated with chest pain often radiating to the back. Symptoms have progressively worsened over the past 4 months.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Weight loss, fatigue, and occasional regurgitation of food.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Underwent endoscopy showing obstructive mass. Biopsy confirmed esophageal malignancy. Initiated on palliative chemotherapy with partial response.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Mental state relatively stable, but noted general weakness and fatigue. Appetite decreased, significant weight loss of 15 lbs in the past month. Normal urination and defecation.

Past History.General Health Condition: Generally good health until current illness.
Past History.Immunization History: Up to date with recommended vaccinations.
Past History.Surgery and Trauma History: Appendectomy at age 25. No major trauma.

Personal History.Living Habits: Non-smoker, occasional wine. Balanced diet though decreased recently due to dysphagia.
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Retired teacher, previously under no significant occupational hazards.
Personal History.Exposure History: No significant exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances.

Marital History.Children's Condition: Two children, both in good health.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Parents both deceased due to natural causes. No siblings.

Systematic Examination.Skin: Pallor noted, no rashes or lesions.
Systematic Examination.Neck: No jugular venous distension, no lymphadenopathy.
Systematic Examination.Chest: Bilaterally symmetrical, clear auscultation, heart sounds normal.
Systematic Examination.Limbs: No edema, normal range of motion.
Systematic Examination.Nervous System: Alert, oriented, cranial nerves intact, no motor or sensory deficits.

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: CT scan showing narrowing of the esophagus with suspicious mass. Biopsy confirmed malignancy.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on dysphagia, chest pain, endoscopic findings, and biopsy results.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Benign esophageal stricture (ruled out by biopsy), achalasia (ruled out by progression and biopsy), esophageal diverticulum (ruled out by endoscopy), esophageal tuberculosis (ruled out by biopsy).

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Prompt admission due to severe dysphagia and progressive chest pain. Initial diagnostic impression strongly suggestive of malignant esophageal tumor. Plan includes staging, oncologist consultation, and palliative care.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Regular assessments showing progressive worsening of dysphagia and increasing weakness. Treatment adjusted to include pain management and nutritional support.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Reviewed on 6th, August. Confirmed severe progression. Advised continuation of palliative care.
Post-Admission Course Records.Difficult Case Discussion Records: Discussed on 7th, August. Confirmed poor prognosis, suggested continuation of symptomatic relief measures.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Noted gradual deterioration, updated next shift on 8th, August.
Post-Admission Course Records.Transfer Records: No inter-hospital or inter-department transfers noted.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Progressive deterioration over hospital stay, no significant improvement in symptoms.
Post-Admission Course Records.Emergency Records: Sudden respiratory distress on 12th, August, managed with nebulization and supportive care.
Post-Admission Course Records.Invasive Procedure Records: None noted during current hospital stay.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Oncology consultation on 6th, August. Advised continuation of palliative chemotherapy.

Surgery Related.Preoperative Summary: Discussed risks given advanced age and disease stage.
Surgery Related.Preoperative Discussion Records: Explored surgical options considering critical anatomy involved.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Preoperative Visit Records: High-risk assessment due to frailty and compromised respiratory function.
Surgery Related.Surgery Records: Palliative esophagectomy performed. Tumor reduced but not fully resectable.
Surgery Related.Postoperative First Course Record: Stable immediately post-operative, later showed signs of respiratory insufficiency.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Postoperative Visit Records: Difficult emergence but stable vitals post-recovery.

Post-Admission Course Records.Discharge Records: Not applicable, patient deceased during stay.

Death Related.Death Case Discussion Records: Sudden cardiac arrest on 15th, August. Resuscitation unsuccessful.
Death Related.Death Records: Time of death: 5:40 PM, 15th, August. Cause: Complications from advanced esophageal malignancy. Attending Physician: Dr. A. Smith

Post-Admission Course Records.Critically Ill Patient Care Records: Constant monitoring and symptomatic care. Regular consultations with palliative care team.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: Nutritional support via NG tube, continuous pain management, regular vital observations.
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Stat doses of morphine for breakthrough pain, diagnostic imaging as needed.

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: CT scan, endoscopy results pre-admission, biopsy confirming malignancy.
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Regular charting showing fever spikes post-operatively settling to normal ranges.
Hospitalization Record.Blood Transfusion Consent: Consented by next-of-kin due to critical anemia post-op.
Hospitalization Record.Special Examination Consent: Consented for endoscopic and imaging procedures.
Hospitalization Record.Critical Condition Notice: Issued to family upon significant deterioration.

Malignant Tumors.Name: Esophageal Malignancy
Malignant Tumors.Symptoms: Dysphagia (difficulty swallowing or feeling of obstruction when food moves down the esophagus, initially for solid food, later for semi-solid food, and finally for liquid food and saliva, indicating a progressive malignant course rather than spasm, benign or digestive strictures); chest pain often radiating to the back.
Malignant Tumors.Differential Diagnosis: Benign esophageal stricture, achalasia, esophageal diverticulum, esophageal tuberculosis, etc.
